revised_title: J. D. Griffith Davies: A Life of Service to the Royal Society
tldr: This article is a biography of J. D. Griffith Davies, who served as the Assistant Secretary of the Royal Society from 1937 to 1946. It highlights his contributions to the Society during a tumultuous period, his passion for history and local institutions, and his dedication to science and its people. Davies was instrumental in organizing the Society's treasures during World War II, introducing modern methods of administration, and supporting scientific refugees. He also played a significant role in the Empire Scientific Conference and the Newton Tercentenary Celebrations. After retirement, he continued his involvement in local activities and established an endowment for the John Wilkins Lecture in the history of science.
